title: Simple fare on a terrace with a view!
text:
A good food tip for Marrakech; avoid the scruffy, overpriced food on the El - fnaa square and inside the Medina and come out here and eat something that doesn't look like a dubious dog's-dinner and in a clean and pleasant environment!
A couple of cooling drinks, hot and delicious skewers with chips and a really nice Seafood Pastilla overlooking The iconic minaret of Koutoubia. Delicious.

title: Beautiful location: cuisine Disappointing
text:
We had Just 3 nights in Fès. First night at El Mokri Palace it was late so we ate in and had beautifully cooked local dishes, but second evening decided to eat nearby at Fès Cafe.
The location in a tranquil garden is alluring! The restaurant looks cosy and welcoming and the menu board seems attractive!
Regrettably the food was at best dreary and not appetising and service a bit longwinded : staff rather detached! Overall, not a good choice and very expensive for what it was!
On our final full day in Fès, we revisited for a quick afternoon drink in the garden: very pleasant , cool and shady and one doesn't hurry, does one? No, but it's neither pleasant nor courteous for the barman to interrupt your tranquility at 3.45 pm to ask you to pay up because the "afternoon shift" is going off duty! Rude and unnecessary - work routines are the establishment's problem , not your customers'!
place: Fez Cafe at Le Jardin Des Biehn

title: The most attractive Gateway
text: The gate itself is , I guess, iconic but not spectacular and the immediate area is very scruffy ! There are a good number of very touristy restaurants in the area just inside the gate all of them with the usual pushy vendors! WALK ON! Smaller cheaper and much less brash outlets inside the Médina!

title: A superb piece of Islamic Architecture
text: In this Madrasa you not only see the impressive courtyard but also the gallery and the individual study rooms for students.

title: You have to see/smell it!!
text: it's tricky to find and at the same time AVOID all the touts! Persevere! There is a high level viewing platform that gives you a better view WITHOUT buying any unwanted " leather trinkets " or overpriced food and drink ( with poor views) So ignore ALL the sham entreaties!

title: A true gem of Islamic Architecture!
text: When you visit an Islamic country which does not allow access to its greatest architectural masterpieces by non-Muslims, you have to make do with the Madrasa! This is a lovely example of the finest Islamic architecture : very fine detail! You only get to see the courtyard but it's still worth the small fee!

title: Lovely little park!
text: It's a nice little park : not intended to be a great tourist attraction but pleasant to linger in for a while and just alongside the Blue gate,

title: Loved it!!
text:
We stayed for 3 nights and thoroughly enjoyed it!
It's a beautiful place! Yes, it's a bit "Heath Robinson" as a hotel, but the sheer delight to 'stay in a beautiful room in a lovely palace' compensates for the little inadequacies and "hit and miss" service" ( which however WORKS perfectly). Hamza was always there as arranged, lovely breakfasts, and two superb dinners served in 19th century splendour!

title: A lovely courtyard cafe
text: We went in for a quick drink on our last morning in Marrakech so cannot comment on the food. It's a lovely spot for that! Sit under the lemon trees and enjoy a citron pressé or café is very pleasant and cool , some lovely and rather unusual tiles too!

title: Tagine and Thé
text: After a visit to the Jardin Majorelle we stopped here for lunch. Lovely individual tagines and of course a pot of thé à la me the!

title: Tiny place but worth a visit
text: Last morning in Marrakech, nothing planned so we paid a visit! It's just a little Riad , two floors with a nice outline of the essentials of "smells"! There is more in the way of olfactory than visual here , but that's its strength as a museum!

title: A modern space dedicated to the Work of Yves Saint Laurent and Pierre Bergé
text: If you are a “Fashion Follower” it’s a must! If not it’s still a nice modern space to see many of the famous man’s most staggering creations! There are also temporary exhibitions . When we were there there was an exhibition of the Artist Jaxques Azéma. The Pierre Bergė ( one time life partner of Saint Laurent )Auditorium is a high tech theatre which shows some lovely footages of Saint Laurent’s work.

title: Fascinating but beware!
text:
The souks and marketplaces of Morocco are one of the main reasons for our visits , but here in Marrakech it is really a mixed pleasure! It is interesting to see some of the smaller side alleys where craftsmen are ( apparently ) plying their ancient trades : copper beating, wood and plaster carving, etc but on those areas directly adjoining the main square , there is mostly tourist trash, and touts, mostly unpleasant!
Today most canny tourists carry around.Mobile phones installed with Google maps and know EXACTLY where they are going. This, is not to the liking of the many, apparently jobless young men, who aggressively repeatedly try to mislead tourists and get very aggressive if you don’t hand over money for their “misinformation” ! Walk ahead and DON’T respond at all!
There are many food vendors on the edge of the central square, they’ve ALL got the same stuff ( mainly grilled skewers of diminutive pieces of meat old vegetables ) and it’s ALL a rip-off! Look our for nice , not flashy little cafes in the back alleys and eat better at half the price!

title: A Little Hidden Oasis!
text: A pretty little garden, but nothing extraordinary! Having previously visited the Menara Gardens ( if you haven’t been don’t bother !! ) it was interesting to see this miniature recreation of a similar irrigation system . Two little gardens linked : Islamic Garden and Tropical Garden, the Islamic one is bigger and more interesting, but the tropical one has a couple of pavilions and a pleasant little cafe to enjoy another pot of mint tea!

title: All a bit run down and scruffy
text:
It’s not really a garden, just a public open space!
The original concept was probably interesting, a large irrigation system with a square artificial tank or pond with a small square pavilion used as a summer residence by a former sultan, Today it’s really just a series of olive fields with the rather sad looking relic of the pond and the pavilion itself fenced off ( you can go in for a rather high fee!) but nobody really seems interested.

title: Symbolic ( but not allowed In!)
text:
It's the "SYMBOL" of Marrakech and is right at the centre of everything and the famous minaret is beautifully restored BUT when will Moroccans learn that they need to stop this silly idea of making mosque interiors off limits to tourists? It's a building : where would Istanbul be if you couldn't see the interior of the Blue Mosque, or Cologne without its Dom??
Not everybody in the country's aim for 20 million tourists only want to ride a camel for half an hour in the Atlas!

title: Big but unspectacular!
text:
By comparison with other more historic palaces to be found in Morocco , this palace is big but really rather dreary! Rooms and courtyards one after the other, some beautiful wooden ceilings , but the overall decor not at all spectacular ( we stayed in a 19th century palace/ hotel in Fès) which was more spectacular than anything here!)
Garden courtyards full of weeds and nothing to commend them.

title: You have to experience it!
text: It was our first stop after arriving in Marrakech! It's a vast buzzing place in the early evening! Berber dancers, snake charmers, barbers , fruit stalls and hundreds of tacky souvenir stalls, dozens of eateries , ALL selling the same things and generally poor value for money! Touts everywhere only out to get money (tips!) for EVERYTHING ( that you'd not even consider giving anywhere else other than in North Africa!)

title: A lovely garden and museum
text:
Perhaps visiting in February was a good idea! Not so many visitors in this lovely but rather small space! Arriving at 11 am only a short queue and not too crowded inside!
A cool and beautiful oasis in this frenetic city! Not normally great fans of museums, we found the small "Majorelle Blue" museum a delightful display of Berber artefacts! An hour is enough! Then cross the road to enjoy a delicious meal or drink at the Gourmet Pause!

title: In Athens, you can't avoid it ......
text:
....but often wish you could!
It's really a rather ordinary large square surrounded by a selection of very ordinary buildings and a permanent traffic jam not helped by totally undisciplined Athenian drivers and its fair share of "tagging" ( No ,NONE of it deserves the description Graffiti - it's just the offensive scribblings if a nation that seems ti have lost every sense of its own purpose!)
Somehow the authorities seem to keep the wall of the Parliament building ( Unknown Warrior Memorial ) clear for the hourly Guard changing ceremony!

title: A compact museum in the Stoa
text:
Generally speaking , we avoid museums in the traditional sense Even in Athens which has so many! In an age where you can do so much electronically , we confine our archeological visits to actual sites like this one which is housed in the reconstructed Stoa of Attalos. It's nicely arranged and you can get an overview in a few minutes , just settling on a few items of particular interest and not become tired of glass boxes!
Afterwards walk a hundred yards across the agora and visit the nearly intact mini Parthenon in the Temple of Hephaestus!

title: Touristy but not too much so!
text: A much calmer atmosphere than in and around Monastiraki and its rather trashy flea markets. Some interesting more up-market shopping and a good selection of restaurants, and in winter at least, not so crowded.

title: A little gem!
text: You come out of the Monastiraki Metro and you'll see this lovely little church. Its really tiny and if it weren't so beautiful inside you'd rightly describe it as a bit cluttered! Like very many monastic Orthodox churches it is full of ikons and religious artefacts : gifts from the faithful over 9 centuries and gave its name " Little Monastery" to the whole square , now more celebrated for restaurants and flea markets.

title: A lovely place
text: This is one of the more interesting monasteries to visit. There are quite a lot if steps to climb, but as with all these monasteries , the view from the top is magnificent. In a sense, for the casual non specialist visitor all of these monasteries are quite similar : a small beautifully decorated church, a few common areas, and simply magnificent views across the principal wonder of a rare piece of geological landscape - the real spectacle of Meteora!

title: It is spectacular!
text:
This is the largest and the highest elevation monastery of the six remaining operational.
The monastery church is quite small and very ornate and it was quite nice to hear a small fraction if the Christmas Day liturgy. From the courtyard there are some spectacular views. There are also some fascinating monastic rooms and an exhibition and souvenir shop , but the chief attraction in all these high perched sanctuaries has to be their scenic locations

title: Fresh fish, nicely presented
text:
It was a spontaneous first visit to Solingen, just for a quick look- around and we stumbled on this fischerstube at lunchtime! Unusual to find a dedicated fish restaurant ANYWHERE in Germany , let alone one that serves rather more than the ubiquitous and insipid pangasius and "Lachsfilet". solicitous service, a nice glass of wine and a generous well cooked piece. of Hake Bergisch style.
If I were to make one observation , as an Englishman ,I would say that the overall size of the serving was rather too large!

title: The other half of Athens ( Architecturally!)
text:
Maybe you come to Athens principally to see remains of it's glorious past! But the past lies upwards of 2500 years ago , and most of it is truly remnants! Athenians in the 21st century also need today's amenities! You may love or hate the modernist architecture and feel of the place but it's primarily for locals who seem to like it? It houses the National Library and the Opera House ( fully booked for our visit) and something called "The Lighthouse" ( atop the Opera House) from which you get spectacular views across the city and the harbour.
The staff love to tell overseas visitors what they can offer!

title: A nice site between Monastiraki and Plaka
text: As with many of Athens' archeological sites, situated as they are within the busy city centre, if you are a historian you may need to enter the site , but as an interested ( but perhaps not totally absorbed tourist ) you can see all of the main elements of the Agora Romana from outside the railings! It's especially attractive at night , floodlit.

title: Very little to see!
text: A handful of very tall columns, and nothing much else to see! ( Another of those sites at half price in the winter season : barely worth that , considering you can see it all from the road that passes by AND Hadrian's Arch)

title: This is a good place to visit!
text: Athens has many archeological sites, many if which are just various piles of stones and if you're lucky a few restored columns! They are archeologically very significant and very important to historians, but less so to the average tourist! The Ancient Agora is a bit different. The reconstructed Stoa is a nice museum, the assorted remnants of other buildings are clearly identifiable , and the highlight for us the ALMOST intact Temple of Hephaestus . A miniature version of the Parthenon it survived because it was used a Greek orthodox church until 1834!

title: A spectacular Amphitheatre!
text: If you're going up to the Acropolis don't bother making a separate visit ( and paying again) because you get a really good view of it from the upward path to the top! It's impressive, but probably more so if you can experience a performance!

title: Lovely views across Athens
text:
If you don't like climbing up steep, steep hills , get a cab up to the foot of the funicular , it's worth it!
A two way ticket costs €7.50 ( worth it) and at the top a few more steps takes you to the top! Some spectacular views across the city and a pretty little Chapel of St George. Can be a bit blustery up there!

title: The quieter part of central Athens....
text: Just a stone's throw from the crowds of Monastiraki you find it is calmer , past Hadrian's great Library and the great buildings of the Agora Romana you pass into Plaka, at the foot of the Acropolis hill. Cc Here you'll find quieter bars and cafes and less touristy shopping! There are also a couple of museums to check out if you're inclined - we weren't!

title: Wow !! (still!)
text:
It's still a marvel to see!
Cleaned and glowing in the winter sun and with only a small area under scaffolding , if you can take the steeper climb up past the Theatre. of Dionysius and the great Odeon!

title: A pleasant experience
text:
One note, if as we did, you visit in the low winter season DON'T be tempted to buy the €30 saver ticket for 5 sites because all the others are half price!
Much changed from my last visit 30 odd years ago! Good and alternative walkways and the summit , whilst still a jumble of stones is much tidier and the still standing monuments really gleaming!

title: An unusual eatery!
text: This is a "Charcuterie" shop with its counter surrounded by a few tables for bistro style dining - but it's a lovely place to eat! Nothing flash about it but offerings derived mainly from the shop 's range of cured and dried meats fish and cheese . The dried finely sliced swordfish , diced tomato and olives with traditional Greek hummus topping was superb!

title: Superb!
text:
This is the way fish and seafood should be served! No unnecessary showmanship but just fresh shellfish and fish with perfect accompaniments. The fresh oysters were superb , and here's the rub: the genuine oyster eater may raise an eyebrow at the idea of a "foam" of Passionfruit and chilli? Really, it works beautifully!
As main course I decided to try the robata of sea bream , a special form of charcoal grilling - a perfect piece of crispy skinned fish on a small bed of equally delicious fresh grilled vegetables!
My partner took the octopus dish, a seafood not really to my taste , and declared it to be " Everything octopus should be" - I'm sure it was!
After such a delight I decided I needed to see if such a fine kitchen could also produce a memorable dessert? I took the chocolate and passionfruit parfait! Thick dense chocolate with chocolate sauce! Again the element of passion fruit made it a small miracle, not sickly sweet but delightful!
Well done Bluefish!

title: Pleasant but unexceptional
text:
The beef noodle soup is really pleasant enough and slices of beef really well cooked and succulent ( if not over generous!) diminutive little side dishes of dried and fried tofu and bamboo shoots added little to the overall enjoyment of the noodle soup!
Would not really consider this as gourmet food.

title: A feast for the eyes but also Delicious!
text:
I have to admit that I have always avoided restaurants who claim that they serve FUSION cuisine, because it's usually that " neither fish nor foul" attempt to make spicy flavourful Asian classics into something totally insipid that Western ( especially German !) palates can manage! Here at Mr T that is DEFINITELY not the case! The restaurant also has that rare ability of serving fine sushi as well as many many other Asian delights : a rarity!
My partner decided to make the choice of all sushi , while I went for mixture of classic starter and Vietnamese speciality! My partner casually suggested having both courses served together - the waitress smiled and said " better separate!" On arrival we see why! Presentation here is superb , both the very special ( fusion!) Sushi and my little tower of avocado and tuna tartare were a delight to see and to taste.
Next came our main course , for my partner more Maki Sushi immaculately presented, including a little snowstorm ball and a flask of dry ice mist! A gimmic perhaps , but not overstated. My own main course was a traditional Vietnamese beef Pho. Now I love Vietnam and know the country and its food quite well. This bowl of Pho was superb - no further comment is needed.

This was a very pleasant first visit! ( oh , and the bill was also a pleasant surprise

title: Poor overall experience!
text:
We visited this restaurant about 2 years ago and were not really very impressed but decided to give it another try!
I wish we hadn't; if anything it has declined even more both in its overall scruffiness and also the quality of the sushi! Furthermore , although it bills itself as " all you can eat " at a fixed price , beware, there are many many items for which attract a hefty supplement which means you leave with a much higher bill than you'd bargained for.
Eating here is still not a particularly rewarding experience!

title: A really "user friendly" museum
text:
I went to the Park and Museum on the first Monday in the month when entrance is free!
Above everything else I was SO surprised to find AT LAST a German museum complex that is genuinely welcoming to international visitors! Everything you need to know is in multiple languages and the staff are welcoming and friendly!
The Park itself is in reality more of an "artist's Impression" than an archaeological site, but the Museuem, constructed over some of the more interesting remnants of the vast Baths complex is well laid out and organised. Not normally being encouraged to linger in German Museums, I actually wished I'd had more time to spend here!

title: A nice place to visit
text:
I went on the first Monday of the month when admission is free - an extra bonus!
The park is very extensive but really has not got a lot to see, but what there is is well displayed and documented ( and always including English). The layout is really nice : wide pathways with mature trees and some clever vistas which highlight the main 'reconstruction sites' ( Harbour Temple , Amphitheatre etc) Around the modern museum building there are are some interesting vestiges of the complex baths complex, but the highlights are more in the nature of 'artists impressions' than real archaeological remains.

title: This is a REALLY LOVELY house to visit!
text:
No it's not Gaudí , and it's nothing like Gaudí,but it's right next door to Casa Batilo and for my money it's much more of a "home' than it's neighbour. The Amatller family were and still are Chocolatiers and entrance to their mansion today includes a finishing treat : a cup of delicious hot chocolate!
The apartment itself is a "work in progress" and the careful guides will take you around armed with tablet guide! These are really lovely rooms tastefully decorated and furnished.
It's beautiful!

title: A lovely museum
text: I'm not a 'museum person' person but this is a lovely place to visit. There is an enormous volume of material here , but above all it is the wonderful works of art from Picasso's early period right through to his later masterpieces and his great love of photography

title: A lovely street!
text: This must be one of Europe's most beautiful thoroughfares! Just walk up and down and marvel at the wonderful architecture - and Gaudí is only one of them!

title: The Arrival is more interesting than the destination!
text:
We took the funicular from Paral lel ( very short unfinished looking ride up to the cable car station. The ride up to the top ( unusual right angle bend half way up!) is quite spectacular, and if not too busy you can have a gondola to yourself! Some lovely views across the city and the port - a bit pricey though!
The citadel is what it says it is : massive but nothing inside , but some good views across the harbour. Nicely laid out gardens in the former most.

title: You know? I was a bit underwhelmed!
text:
I booked online on the OFFICIAL site ( Don't use the other unofficial sites !!) and did not have to queue in the rain! The first let down was that the rooftop was closed ( no reason given!)
Insude then ,you have the attic space ( basically just a museum with nothing much in it - but nevertheless interesting to see those rib cage arches! Then down to the apartment! Nice to see how modest it really is and to look out at that wonderful contorted ironwork of the balconies - and basically that's it! Not great value for money!

title: It's ordinary, but it's fine!
text:
This was my second visit to Barcelona and to this particular restaurant. In the time since I last visited I have been to several other tapas restaurants around the city, some good, some awful, some "celebrated" and some very overpriced! I would say that this place is really pretty good value for money and fine for a simple and not overpriced lunch. It's not pretentious, the innovation is not spectacular, but the quality and size of different tapas is consistent!
I liked it and very importantly didn't feel "ripped off"

title: An enjoyable visit
text:
It can be a very busy place all year round and online DIRECT booking is a good idea!
With advanced booking timing can be a problem . It was a wet day and I had arrived rather early in the Passeig de Gracia and approached a young lady at the entrance and was told that with my ticket I could actually go inside earlier and not queue in the rain!
Yes, the house is truly remarkable!

title: A real seafood treat!
text:
Staying nearby and always on the lookout for FRESH seafood, we came here twice during our short stay in the Sants area.

A few reviewers seem to have issues about this remarkable little gem : rudeness and pressure from staff, lack of choice of cooking sauces etc., but seem to forget the one thing that a seafood restaurant MUST offer , VERY FRESH PRODUCTS!

This is NO smart or snobbish restaurant! The serving staff are really switched on, and in their special way very friendly and helpful. , even to the stupid non-Spanish speaking customer!

Over our two visits we enjoyed

Beautiful fresh oysters
baby clams and baby octopus with garlic
Superb scallops ( with coral)
large clams with tomato sauce
Giant grilled Prawns

All superb!

title: Not worth the effort of getting here!
text: At the time of our visit it resembled a building site with much of the area fenced off for renovation. Billed as a Hanok Village : village it's certainly not, but just a collection of 5 Hanok style houses assembled from elsewhere! They are all rather similar and quite dreary!

title: A nice Museum
text:
If, like myself you are not a great lover of large rambling 19th Century Museums, crammed with thousands of artefacts over umpteen floors and galleries , this is one for you!
It's modern, it's light, it's airy and is just one long building with just 3 levels with a very "constrained" number of exhibits covering some quite precise subject areas.
Entrance to the main collection is free.
A little word of warning, in busy times the galleries are quite manageable, but don't be tempted to try the food hall!

title: The best of the Big Palaces!
text:
This Palace also houses the Korean National Palace Museum and the National Folk Museum.
Because it was the biggest remaining Korean palace , the whole complex was systematically destroyed during the Japanese Occupation at the beginning of the 20th Century, and is slowly being rebuilt , including demolition of former Japanese government buildings to recreate the majestic Palace gateways! So everything you see today is very recent.

title: It's a really big network, but.....,
text:
First of all the money card is a very good idea: just tap and go anywhere.

Avoid rush hours : it can be very busy, if like myself you are no "Spring Chicken" don't hesitate to enforce your right to a priority seat! Young Seoulites don't like to give up their seats but will do so if they have to! If you have NAVER Map app. on your mobile it can be very useful when accessing or leaving Metro stations because. MANY of them have VERY limited escalator or lift access to street level, and lines are very deep resulting in long,long staircases ! NAVER will tell you where the escalators and lifts are!

title: Overall , not over impressed!
text:
It was our first day in Seoul, and having our small rented apartment nearby and it was a free entry day, it was our first visit!
If I say it set the tone for similar visits over our 4 days in Seoul , I would not say we were greatly impressed! The great halls are quite impressive in themselves ( although most parts are later reconstructions resulting from hostile events in Japanese/Korean history! However , overall, the site seems to lack any coherence to help the visitor to understand the history of the place! There is very little access INTO any of these buildings and rather too many notices " Do not step!" A big minus point in this and seemingly most of the central Seoul historic sites is the use of SAND on most of the pathways in the complex! Seoul seems to be quite a windy city , even when summer temperatures top 35 degrees, everything is covered in a thin layer sand , including visitors! We did pay for a guided tour of the Secret Garden, really not a greatly rewarding experience ( even if you could understand the guide's English ) but you're not allowed to go around except on a tour?

title: It's still an attraction!
text: Most towns have their trams or underground but Wuppertal has its "floating railway line along the Wupper. For the locals it's a regular means of transport but for the visitor it's a novelty!

title: Really nothing special
text: It's in a very nice location ( if you can manage the steep hilly terrain) but like so many tourist attractions in Germany , looks a bit run down and scruffy! There are a lot of really big , purpose built enclosures but most have either far too few ( or no animals ) in them!

title: A really nice experience
text:
Went with friends ( six altogether) for a steamboat dinner which was very pleasant. We were lucky to have a very helpful waitress who took charge of the " mechanics" of the meal for us including serving to less adept customers. This ensured a smooth passage through the various foods to be cooked!
A good experience!

title: Old style Chinese restaurant
text:
Entering it's a bit gloomy and certainly more of an "old establishment" feel about it. It was not overcrowded so service was quick if somewhat " take it or leave it" with little or no smiles and welcome touches!
Dim sum, also "old style" with trolled but tasty and authentic. Not a bad experience but not noteworthy either!

title: A step back in history
text: It's a Kampung house which is still lived in by the owner and his family. A charming and polite old man and a nice , short , visit. Bash the family gong as you leave and make a wish!

title: The nicest of all Nyonya restaurants we've trued
text:
This restaurant came highly recommended and didn't fail!
We arrived early, and the owner/chef came to our table to advise us about his special suggestions. Two light pork items as starter, followed by a Nyonya Assam fish fillet, pineapple/spice prawns, Sweet potato leaves with yam in creamy laksa sauce, and Otak-Otak
followed by the "pièce de résistance" the famous Nyonya Cendol with extra gula-melaka.
Fabulous

title: A hotel? Or a private museum?
text:
That's the question I have to ask after a night's stay at 5 Heeren, because the two functions do not necessarily fit together very well!

As a museum , the "public areas " work well, but as free access and comfort for hotel guests , paying a premium price they do not work so well! The assertion that visiting guests should "feel at home" here is not really valid, because antique or no, the ground floor is too cluttered and "museumy" to be anything but awkwardly uncomfortable!
It's nice to stay in a hotel that is "apart" from the normal, but there are times ,as here, where sparing use is better than "overkill"!
Turning to the rooms ( which in spite of an overall museum ambience) must perform the hotel function of rest, relaxation and a good night's sleep) the opposite to the public spaces seems to apply. Regular rooms are nicely themed, also with their selection of antiques BUT are generally small, and lacking in "comfort" - no soft chairs, no nice bath to relax in, and a pretty basic ( not luxury) set of toiletries and no feel of freshly laundered "fluffy towels".
Breakfast though was a real pleasure!

title: Everything was awful
text:
Billed as a classical nonya restaurant NOTHING served came even close to tasty food!
Four dishes cane out all items plonked onto what appeared to be a half of a lollo bionda lettuce and a few slices of raw tomato and cucumber? What on earth has that sort of presentation got to do with good Malacca cuisine?

The fish was diminutive and dry, the supposedly spicy devilled chicken was dry and tasteless , the Otak-Otake was rubbery ( more like Spam) and the only slightly tasty item was the brinjal . but the grey sauce looked very unappetising!

The staff too , all came over as sullen and TOTALLY disinterested!

A thoroughly bad choice!

title: A nice setting , interesting exhibits, but...
text:
And it's a big but..... the staff from the lady at the reception to the various attendants in the galleries are AWFUL!!

I asked for two tickets at €3.50 each and proffered a €10 note only to get a snarled " I've got no small change" , but she had: just didn't want to part with it! The activities of the gallery staff could only be described as " prowling and scowling " and dictatorial about the "correct " route to be followed , a route with no logic whatsoever!

The exhibition itself seems quite well arranged and the Rubens paintings are hung in a very beautiful setting, and other rooms with paintings ,engravings, furnishings and musical instruments are worth seeing , but why is EVERYTHING labelled only in German? Rubens and the various branches of the Nassau family are of international importance and might at least have English and Dutch translations.

I'm sorry, but these types of criticism are too often a feature of tourist centres in Germany which seem to have little grasp of what makes tourism work in modern times!

title: Nothing special
text:
Went into the restaurant for a quick Sunday lunchtime snack and the food was OK, but nothing special!
It's basically a noodle bar, with mostly bar seating area and a bit difficult to get around! My noodle soup with pork and sauerkraut was pleasant enough, but the noodles were a bit too 'al dente' for my taste and pieces of pork diminutive and difficult to find! Not exactly good value for €10 +. I'd be inclined to use the description " student eatery" but not at that price!

title: Not a good experience!
text:
We had visited previously on a couple of occasions and been a bit “underwhelmed” but having been given a “Gutschein” we decided to try again with a visiting friend. Not a good idea I’m afraid.

First, the place is incredibly scruffy! No, I don’t think the place is dirty; just totally lacking the TLC that that can make a restaurant a memorable and satisfying experience. It being a very warm evening our reserved table was outside on the terrace: a reasonable decision!

In my opinion, the menu selection in some ways mirrors the locale itself, bland and unimaginative, but certainly not at the lower end of the price range. Two of us ordered the veal cordon blue and the other the Senfrostbraten. My Veal Cordon Bleu was diminutive ,
cut in two pieces, sitting on a VERY salty but characterless orange coloured sauce, and with some obviously old and very tough green asparagus and some blond potato croquettes taken straight from a freezer pack! My partner rated the Senfrostbrsten in a similar fashion! Two desserts also followed the same pattern.

I am sorry, but when I am paying over 110 Euros for 3 meals I need much better value than this!

title: A really pleasant park.
text:
Living in Essen for a few years, and with a visitor to entertain on a warm sunny day, this was a first "proper " visit to Grugapark.
It's a really nice place to visit with attractions for all types of visitors. The landscaping in the special gardens is very pleasant and the "hop on- hop off train enables visitors to see all parts of the garden with ease.
Regrettably, in common with many public amenities in Europe generally , and Nordrhein Westfalen particularly,reductions in public funding for "lower priority" projects is beginning to show ! There are some nice displays , but quite noticeably, not enough staff and resources to maintain them properly.

title: Mixed Feelings!
text:
It's probably the "world's most beautiful coal mine" and if you take a tour, for those with a specific interest in Industrial archeology, it is probably a fascinating experience. However , as a site of "general" tourist interest it has some shortcomings. The site is very large and seems to lack many "user friendly" essentials.
1) signposting around the perimeter is not very clear for arriving motorists, and within the site does not seem to give walking distances!
2) although much of the site is broadly speaking " open access" much of it is of no great interest, taken over by independent operators and it is easy to waste time on fruitless wandering with no signposts,
3) The initial impression of the reception area in the washing plant is good, the long escalator, with good views going upward. and the A/C interior, but once inside it all seems very sterile! Some assistants in the information centre seem lost when asked questions in English, and a cafeteria manned by a lady who is seemingly " chewing on a wasp" and uncleared tables, is not in sync with the little fresh flower bouquets !
place: Zollverein Coal Mine Industrial Complex in Essen

title: A reliably good meal before shopping
text:
This is an "Imbiss" or snack bar attached the superb Asian Supermarket next door and we always look forward to a good meal there before shopping. Honestly, we've NEVER been disappointed! It's not fine dining but every dish comes straight from the wok, is ample and good tasting. There are not so many restaurants where you can get such a good freshly prepared meal for €10.!
We missed you when you were closed for a refit, but now you're much brighter and cheery.

title: Could not fault it!
text:
An unscheduled visit to Bolkerstraße on Düsseldorf 's annual Japanese Day is risky if you want to find somewhere to eat, but we found a table away from the crowds more interested in "Happy Hour" cocktails!
Our choices were predominantly based on Crispy spring rolls and a Bun Cha and a Bun Bo Hue.
I chose the Bun bo Hué as I last had it in a small cafe just outside Hué railway station some years ago. Here in Düsseldorf it was different but in a very nice but , I think , authentic way. Similarly the Bun Cha Hà Nội was not so far from our experience in Hanoi last year.

Nice food at very good price.

title: Neat and tidy, courteous service...
text:
We have been doing a regular "Sunday Search" for Asian restaurants in the Düsseldorf/Duisburg/ Essen area of NRW that get away from the all too familiar "All you can eat" formula of generic German style asian cuisine! After 2 disasters and one success we decided to give this small restaurant a try last Sunday evening. As our previous weekend had produced a "good" result we decided to keep to dim sum to get a comparison.
Broadly speaking DimSum Bistro in Bilk came out pretty well. The little restaurant is light and airy and very clean and the service is courteous and all 7 items came in manageable relays, and were hot and freshly prepared.Most were excellent but a couple missed the mark for us, the Black bean pork ribs were tasty but undercooked and very difficult to get the meat off the bones! The beef balls with lemon grass and spinach were too big as dim sum and too dense and chewy! We were a little disappointed with the two types of Chee Cheong Fun which were not those light slippery rice noodles but more like rice paper - however the taste was good.
Another little "plus" : it was good to have a choice of chinese teas and not only the cheap and often nasty jasmine tea - Pu errh is the best companion for Dim sum.

Overall a nice meal at a reasonable price

title: A nice Cathedral to visit
text: After the rush of Barcelona ,Tarragona is a pleasant contrast, especially the lovely cathedral. Beautifully cleaned and restored it is a really wonderful building. The entry ticket also includes several rooms off the cloister which contain the treasures of the cathedral and the cloister garden itself.
place: Catedral Basilica Metropolitana Primada de Tarragona

title: A marvellous construction
text:
We'd decided to visit the aqueduct on our way from Calaf to Tarragona and surprise, surprise it's accessible directly from the Motorway, so no
parking or entry charges! You just walk a few yards from the motorway parking to the top
of the aqueduct and take a walk across this well preserved Roman monument. Well worth a short stop before visiting the other Roman sites in this calm city.

title: First time visit
text:
If you want to enjoy some good and pretty authentic Chinese food just give the ubiquitous "all you can eat" formula a miss and try this Restaurant. For me, one of the great delights of Chinese cuisine to be enjoyed in China and South East Asia is dim sum, and here you can enjoy dozens of different types , all prepared with care and not just taken from a convenient freezer pack. There are of course the regular favourites, but much more.
From the outside it's not the most flashy place , and inside it's well used, the menu cards are a touch tatty, but the welcome and that important item , the food is excellent!.
I think we shall return again : probably many times, and the prices for these little gems are very appealing!

title: Consistently missed the mark
text:
We have been to quite a number of these "automated ordering" restaurants in Asia and they usually work well : here it just didn't! The kitchen and serving staff just appeared unable to keep pace with the automation! We went for Sunday lunch ( the limited menu option) and the initial few items arrived quite swiftly , but of the second ordering nothing came at all - a rather surly waiter just said "It's in the system" but it evidently wasn't and after 45 minutes waiting pencil and paper took over from Tablet!
Concerning the food itself, I have to say I've eaten worse sushi , but I've also eaten much better - execution moderate at best. Of other items, (soups, skewers, fish and warm meats there were a few quite pleasant items but too many were "just very ordinary" and often lukewarm and a bit "gloopy".
Like so many eateries in Germany it is principally let down by really indifferent service and no attention to detail!

title: A pleasant meal
text: Wanted something quick and it was fine. pleasant staff And food , while not distinguished was served quickly and pleasant.

title: From outside it looks quite plush : inside not well organised!
text:
When you've just missed your train on a public holiday and need to kill half an hour you need to leave the station and find a bar!
Did just that!
A whole battery of staff inside , all getting in each other's way and ducking back and forth under an apparently non hinged bar!
Ordered a couple of glasses of wine which came quickly , so asked to pay straight away as we'd limited time! Result: total confusion!

title: Not really impressed!
text:
After hearing "rave" reviews from the younger generation we thought we'd give it a try.
Perhaps not a good idea to chose a public holiday in Germany ( when everything in Limbecker Platz has that funereal aspect - but that's not Five Guys fault!) . Having said that, we were not really over-impressed! Firstly, it's not a cheap option! The venue is quite spartan, and honestly, the burgers are nothing special! For my taste the burger itself seemed a bit dry and insipid and the bun nondescript! Perhaps this was partly because as some one who is not keen on burgers " swimming" with mayo and gurkins I opted only for tomato and Jalapeño, but I didn't expect the meat and bacon to be so dried out!
At a time when we are all exhorted to be environmentally aware there seemed to be an awful lot of packaging including plastic and foil!
If ( as often in Asia) I get a burger from an auto machine I expect it to be foil packed, but from a specialist over the counter outlet it's not very elegant! Rather liked the spicy fries but much too SALTY.
Finally. the drinks machines were not working well! OK in quiet moments but a disaster if busy!
